content: The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to provide financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. Depository institutions are not liable for disclosing financial records to state child support enforcement agencies under the "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993." State agencies can only disclose these records for the purpose of establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations. The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows state agencies to disclose financial records for child support purposes only. If a state officer discloses a financial record in violation of the Act, the individual can sue for damages in federal court. No liability exists for good faith but erroneous interpretation. No liability arises for good faith, but erroneous, interpretation of subsection (b). In any action for unauthorized disclosure of financial records, the defendant is liable for damages. In cases of unauthorized disclosure of financial records, the defendant is liable for actual damages, punitive damages in cases of willful disclosure or gross negligence, and the costs of the action. The term "depository institution" is defined for the purpose of this section. The term "financial record" is defined in the Right to Financial Privacy Act of 1978 and includes records from depository institutions, institution-affiliated parties, credit unions, and their affiliated parties. The term "State child support enforcement agency" refers to a State agency that administers a program for establishing and enforcing child support obligations. State child support enforcement agencies can access and use consumer reports in child support cases. State child support enforcement agencies can access consumer reports for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations if paternity is established or acknowledged by the consumer according to state laws. State child support enforcement agencies must provide written notice to the consumer before obtaining a consumer report and certify to the consumer reporting agency that all necessary requirements have been fulfilled. The term 'State child support enforcement agency' is defined as a State agency that administers a program for establishing and enforcing child support obligations. SEC. 4. HEALTH CARE SUPPORT. In Child Support Orders, Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for any child support order issued or modified by a court or administrative agency of the State. State guidelines under section 467(d) of the Social Security Act provide for coverage of health care costs for children and expedited procedures for addressing noncompliance with child support orders. The Secretary requires each State to establish guidelines for covering health care costs of children under child support orders, meeting minimum standards set by regulations. The guidelines established for covering health care costs of children under child support orders must meet minimum standards, including the contents of the order, responsibility distribution, and provisions for health insurance coverage and claims. The guidelines for covering health care costs under child support orders include insurance information rights, coverage denial circumstances, penalties for non-compliance, and adjustments for changing parental circumstances. The Secretary shall develop standards for state guidelines on child support, prioritizing the child's best interests, parents' financial circumstances, and cost-effectiveness. These guidelines will be subject to regulations within 9 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue proposed regulations within 14 months of the Act's enactment to implement amendments, and final regulations will be issued to include dependent health insurance in the Incentive Payments Program due to successful enforcement. The Social Security Act is amended to consider successful enforcement of a support order for health insurance as support collection from the absent parent. The amount collected in such cases will be included in the Incentive Payments Program. The Social Security Act is amended to include the savings to the State from providing health insurance to children of absent parents. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will prescribe regulations for implementation, and a study will be conducted to determine the impact. Services will conduct a study to determine incentives for States to enforce noncustodial parents' obligations to pay for children's health and dental expenses. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit a report to the House of Representatives within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The study on incentives for States to enforce noncustodial parents' obligations to pay for children's health and dental expenses will be submitted to the House of Representatives and the Senate's Committee on Finance. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REPORTS ON STATE COMPLIANCE WITH TIME LIMITS FOR CHILD SUPPORT ASSISTANCE. Amends the Social Security Act to include compliance with established standards as a reporting requirement for states. SEC. 6. Employers must withhold wages to pay child support obligations to the state within 10 days; late payment penalty imposed. Employers must withhold wages to pay child support obligations to the state within 10 days; late payment penalty of $1,000 imposed for failure to comply. The amendments under section 454 must be approved by the end of the following calendar quarter. The effective date of the amendments is the date of enactment, applying to wages paid after that date and payments under part D of title IV for quarters after that date. Delay is allowed if state legislation is required for implementation. In the case of a State plan approved under section 454 of the Social Security Act, if State legislation is needed for the plan to meet additional requirements imposed by amendments, the plan will not be considered non-compliant solely for failing to meet those requirements before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter after the close of the 1st regular. The State plan approved under section 454 of the Social Security Act must meet additional requirements imposed by amendments by the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter after the close of the 1st regular session of the State legislature. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session. SEC. 7. NATIONAL PARENT LOCATOR NETWORK. The Social Security Act is amended to expand the Parent Locator Service into a national network, allowing states to locate absent parents owing child support or involved in visitation enforcement by accessing records from other state agencies. The Parent Locator Service is expanded into a national network, allowing states to access information from other agencies and sources to locate absent parents and child support orders. The Parent Locator Service is expanded nationally, allowing states to access information to locate absent parents and child support orders. Requests for information are processed online for immediate needs or batch processed periodically. Requests are directed to individual states or federal agencies, with a maximum 48-hour turnaround time. The Parent Locator Service allows states to access information to locate absent parents and child support orders with a maximum 48-hour turnaround time for information broadcast and ready access to courts.
